text: Could someone that was working in the translations team at the R Project Sprint update: <https://github.com/r-devel/r-project-sprint-2023/issues/30>? It looks to me like several more of the goals were met during the sprint, but it would be better for people involved to summarise what was done/what is left to do.

attachments.text:
*Discussed in <https://github.com/r-devel/r-project-sprint-2023/discussions/28|r-devel/r-project-sprint-2023#28>*

Originally posted by *giscus[bot]* August 21, 2023

*R Project Sprint 2023 - Translating R Messages/Warnings/Errors*

<https://contributor.r-project.org/r-project-sprint-2023/projects/translation/|https://contributor.r-project.org/r-project-sprint-2023/projects/translation/>
attachments.title: #30 Project: Translating R Messages/Warnings/Errors

elements.text: Could someone that was working in the translations team at the R Project Sprint update:
? It looks to me like several more of the goals were met during the sprint, but it would be better for people involved to summarise what was done/what is left to do.

text: <@U05S0QQCWBW> I have sent you an invite to the R-devel GitHub organization, so that I can add you to the team that has push access.

elements.text: I have sent you an invite to the R-devel GitHub organization, so that I can add you to the team that has push access.

text: Although the wiki has been a simple way to get started, perhaps in the long term the translation documentation should move to a separate guide, i.e. a bookdown or similar like the R Development Guide. Perhaps this could take over the `translations` repo and we move the dashboard to a `translations-dashboard` repo so they get deployed at <https://contributor.r-project.org/translations> and <https://contributor.r-project.org/translations-dashboard> respectively. This would have the advantage that people could make PRs on the documentation and there would be more control over the navigation (the wiki menu has to be in alphabetical order which doesn't always make sense). What do people think - is this a good idea?

elements.text: Although the wiki has been a simple way to get started, perhaps in the long term the translation documentation should move to a separate guide, i.e. a bookdown or similar like the R Development Guide. Perhaps this could take over the
translations

respectively. This would have the advantage that people could make PRs on the documentation and there would be more control over the navigation (the wiki menu has to be in alphabetical order which doesn't always make sense). What do people think - is this a good idea?

text: Meanwhile, I've updated the teams on the R-devel org: "Everyone" has write access, "translations" has maintain access and "translations-dashboard" has admin access to the current `translations` repo. Could I have a volunteer from the translations group to be upgraded to an owner of the R-devel org to help add people as necessary to the R-devel org and these translation teams?

translations

text: I'm happy to help :raising_hand:

text: although asking for clarification: do we plan to add all translators to the `translators` group, or only the listed lang team leaders?

text: language leader(s) who has PR maintenance experience are better,usually people don't need to care about other languages right?

text: if you decide to use the suggested "review workflow" instead of letting anyone contribute to the Catalan translations without reviews, we could could also set up the Catalan language team. let me know if you are interested

elements.text: if you decide to use the suggested "review workflow" instead of letting anyone contribute to the Catalan translations without reviews, we could could also set up the Catalan language team. let me know if you are interested

text: Agreed, this is for leaders that may also contribute to the general infrastructure (general/language-specific guidelines etc) and will be able to review PRs etc.

elements.text: Agreed, this is for leaders that may also contribute to the general infrastructure (general/language-specific guidelines etc) and will be able to review PRs etc.

text:
That sounds quite useful in the long run! Maybe a GitHub page deployed through the translations repo? Or if there is sufficient material then a separate bookdown? Or extend the translations chapter in the R dev guide - with more sub-chapters or sub-sections?

The Python dev guide has a more exhaustive chapter/section on Translations.

text: Yes, it could be a Quarto website or something other than bookdown. For the dev container project we used mkdocs as we didn't actually need any literate programming, only markdown files: <https://contributor.r-project.org/r-dev-env/>.

elements.text: Yes, it could be a Quarto website or something other than bookdown. For the dev container project we used mkdocs as we didn't actually need any literate programming, only markdown files:

text: I think it's an excellent idea, with Maris we talked about pros and cons of the wiki and we think it was great during the spring but we need something with a little more organization for the future!

elements.text: I think it's an excellent idea, with Maris we talked about pros and cons of the wiki and we think it was great during the spring but we need something with a little more organization for the future!

text: what's the different between translation repo and r-translation repo? just seems really different.

elements.text: what's the different between translation repo and r-translation repo? just seems really different.

text: `r-translations` was created for a workshop, `translation` includes source code for dashboards on svn and subversion + hosts the translation-related issues that are organized in the project planner

elements.text: r-translations
was created for a workshop,
translation
includes source code for dashboards on svn and subversion + hosts the translation-related issues that are organized in the project planner

text: I agree, I think the option I would be least inclined to go for is to keep extending the translations chapter in the R dev guide, other than that generating a quarto website deployed through the translations repo sounds like a neat and flexible alternative
